title: Bishop orders schools not to teach yoga because it’s not Christian
text:
The schools have been told to use Christian mindfulness instead (Picture: E+)

A bishop has asked Catholic schools to stop teaching children yoga because it goes against the Christian faith.

Bishop Alphonsus Cullinan told the schools that practices like yoga are ‘not capable of opening our hearts up to God.’

He instead advised schools to ‘incorporate Christian mindfulness instead’, which he said was ‘not mindlessness, but is meditation based on Christ’.

Highlighting that October is the month of the rosary, the Bishop encouraged staff to ‘pray the rosary’ and help the children to spend time with Jesus in adoration instead of meditating.

The Bishop sent the letter to school staff in his Waterford and Lismore diocese, in southern Ireland, on October 10, slamming the practice of yoga.

He also referred to Pope Francis’s 2015 homily in which he said: ‘Practices like yoga are not capable of opening our hearts up to God.’

Bishop Alphonsus Cullinan encouraged staff to ‘pray the rosary’ and to help children to spend time with Jesus in adoration instead of meditating

Bishop Cullinan said the Pope’s views were ‘very much in accordance with the spirit’ of the ‘Grow in Love’ programme, a new religious education series designed for Irish schools.

The Bishop is no stranger to controversy.

Last year, he faced condemnation from members of the Irish Parliament after announcing plans to establish a ‘delivery ministry’ of exorcists to deal with evil spirits.

The decision came after warnings by controversial Irish exorcist Father Pat Collins who said Ireland was facing a ‘tsunami of evil’.

Fr Collins said there had been ‘an exponential growth in requests’ for a deliverance ministry to deal with demonic activity, writing in the November issue of Intercom magazine, which is published by the Catholic Bishops.

The exorcist, who has been ordained for 48 years, added: ‘There is objective statistical evidence in all Western countries that there is a growing need for this kind of ministry.’

He also criticised ‘spiritual pilgrims’ for getting involved in things like yoga, reiki, witchcraft, fortune telling and consulting mediums.
